text: Thymocyte-thymic epithelial cell interaction leads to high-level replication of human immunodeficiency virus exclusively in mature <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) CD8 ( - ) CD3 ( + ) thymocytes : a critical role for <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interleukin-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
This work aims at identifying the thymocyte subpopulation able to support human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) replication under the biological stimuli of the thymic microenvironment .

In this report we demonstrate that interaction with thymic epithelial cells ( TEC ) induces a high-level replication of the T-tropic primary isolate HIV-1 ( B-LAIp ) exclusively in the mature <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) CD8 ( - ) CD3 ( + ) thymocytes .

<extra_id_0> Tumor necrosis factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> interleukin-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , secreted during this interaction , are critical cytokines for HIV long terminal repeat transactivation through NF-kappaB - dependent activation .

text: <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the major inducer of NF-kappaB and particularly of the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex , whereas <extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> acts as a cofactor by sustaining the expression of the <extra_id_0> p75 TNF receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: The requirement for <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is further confirmed by the observation that the inability of the intermediate <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) CD8 ( - ) CD3 ( - ) thymocytes to replicate the virus is associated with a defect in <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production during their interaction with TEC and correlates with the absence of nuclear NF-kappaB activity in these freshly isolated thymocytes .

Addition of exogenous <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to the intermediate thymocyte cultures induces NF-kappaB activity and is sufficient to promote HIV replication in the cocultures with TEC .

The other major subpopulation expressing the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor , namely , the double-positive ( DP ) <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) CD8 ( + ) CD3 ( +/- ) thymocytes , despite the entry of the virus , do not produce a significant level of virus , presumably because they are unresponsive to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Together , these data suggest that in vivo , despite an efficient entry of the virus in all the <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) subpopulations , a high viral load may be generated exclusively within the mature <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) CD8 ( - ) CD3 ( + ) subset of thymocytes .

However , under conditions of inflammatory response after infection , <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might also be present in the intermediate thymocyte compartment , leading to efficient HIV replication in these cells .
